Guide to the Virginia W. Warthin collection of photographs and illustrations of Brooklyn and Manhattan
                    <num>V1990.048</num>

unittitle.value: Virginia W. Warthin collection of photographs and illustrations of Brooklyn and Manhattan

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Virginia W. Warthin collection of photographs and illustrations of Brooklyn and Manhattan, V1990.048, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

Virginia W. Warthin (nee Whittier; 1912-1995) was the great grand daughter of James Eaton, a Brooklyn resident who owned land on Schermerhorn Street in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood. Her grandmother and great aunt were Virginia and Sarah Eaton who grew up in Brooklyn and attended public schools. In 1918, the family's land on Schermerhorn Street was taken by eminent domain on which the city built the Children's Court. The family then moved to Sidney Place, also in Brooklyn Heights. Virginia W. Warthin attended Brooklyn Friends School. She later married Thomas A. Warthin, a physician, and they had three sons. After retirement, the Warthins lived in Walpole, MA.

The Virginia W. Warthin collection of photographs and illustrations of Brooklyn and Manhattan consists of 13 black-and-white images of late 19th century Brooklyn and Manhattan. The collection includes one albumen print showing a street scene of the Blizzard of 1888 as seen from Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn Heights, as well as 12 halftone reproductions of photographs and illustrations of views of the Brooklyn waterfront looking towards the lower Manhattan cityscape; a view of the Louis Bossert & Son Box Factory building in Brooklyn; and views of 19th century skyscrapers and surrounding buildings in lower Manhattan.
